unnormalised: My first solo road trip in India started with a chai and a prayer. The destination: Pondicherry, from Chennai. I’d prepped for weeks, downloading offline maps, checking my Maruti Suzuki Swift (reg no. TN05AB1234), and mentally preparing for the 150 km stretch. I told my Amma I would call her every 2 hours. She said she would be lighting a diya for my safety.
normalised: My first solo road trip in India started with a chai and a prayer. The destination: Pondicherry, from Chennai. I had prepped for weeks, downloading offline maps, checking my Maruti Suzuki Swift (registration number T-N zero five A-B one two three four), and mentally preparing for the one hundred and fifty kilometer stretch. I told my Amma I would call her every two hours. She said she would be lighting a diya for my safety.

unnormalised: Leaving Chennai at 6:00 AM sharp felt exhilarating. The initial stretch on the East Coast Road (ECR) was smooth, the highway stretching like a ribbon against the backdrop of the Bay of Bengal. The sunrise was breathtaking, painting the sky in hues of orange and pink. I stopped for breakfast at a roadside eatery near Mahabalipuram. Idli-vada and filter coffee for just Rs. 80 – a steal! The owner, a friendly chap named Kumar, told me to be careful of the "speed breakers" up ahead.
normalised: Leaving Chennai at six A-M sharp felt exhilarating. The initial stretch on the East Coast Road (E-C-R) was smooth, the highway stretching like a ribbon against the backdrop of the Bay of Bengal. The sunrise was breathtaking, painting the sky in hues of orange and pink. I stopped for breakfast at a roadside eatery near Mahabalipuram. Idli-vada and filter coffee for just rupee eighty – a steal! The owner, a friendly chap named Kumar, told me to be careful of the "speed breakers" up ahead.

unnormalised: The next leg was a bit more challenging. Traffic started to pick up, and I encountered my fair share of overloaded trucks and aggressive auto-rickshaw drivers vying for space. I even saw a camel cart! The road conditions varied - sometimes smooth four-lane highways, and sometimes narrow two-lane stretches with potholes that threatened to swallow my tires whole. I learned to navigate the chaos with a mix of caution and assertiveness, relying heavily on my trusty horn.

unnormalised: Around 10:30 AM, I reached a small town, marked only by a faded signboard. The GPS showed I was still 50 km from Pondicherry. I decided to take a detour off the main highway, hoping to explore the countryside. The roads narrowed even further, winding through fields of paddy and coconut groves. I passed through several villages, each with its own unique charm – children playing cricket, women drawing kolams outside their homes, and men gathered around tea stalls, discussing politics. This was the India I had been yearning to see, raw and unfiltered. I got a flat tire near a small village. I was able to change it, but the spare was not in top condition. I decided to get it repaired in Pondicherry.

unnormalised: I finally reached Pondicherry around 1:00 PM, exhausted but thrilled. The French colonial architecture was a welcome change from the dusty highways. I checked into my guesthouse, "Villa Shanti" (tariff: Rs. 2500 per night), and immediately headed to the beach. The sound of the waves crashing against the shore was incredibly soothing.
normalised: I finally reached Pondicherry around one P-M, exhausted but thrilled. The French colonial architecture was a welcome change from the dusty highways. I checked into my guesthouse, "Villa Shanti" (tariff: rupee two thousand five hundred per night), and immediately headed to the beach. The sound of the waves crashing against the shore was incredibly soothing.

unnormalised: Over the next few days, I explored Pondicherry – the Aurobindo Ashram, the French Quarter, and the beaches. I rented a scooter (Rs. 300 per day) and zipped around the town, soaking in the atmosphere. I ate delicious seafood, sipped on refreshing coconut water, and watched the sunset from the Promenade. Pondicherry was everything I had hoped for – a blend of Indian and French cultures, a laid-back vibe, and a sense of history.

unnormalised: The return journey to Chennai on 18/12/2023, was less adventurous but equally memorable. I stopped at several more roadside dhabas, savoring the flavors of Tamil Nadu. I reflected on my solo road trip – the challenges, the discoveries, and the sheer joy of being on the road. It was an experience that changed me, teaching me to be more independent, resilient, and appreciative of the beauty of India. I am planning my next trip in April, 2024. I am hoping to travel from Bangalore to Goa.
